Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Pran Nath, Brent D. Nelson, and Tomasz R. Taylor at Northeastern University.

After nearly forty years of experimental searches, the Higgs boson (the particle that is responsible for giving mass to all the particles in the universe) has been discovered in experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). After the discovery of the Higgs boson, the LHC has been upgraded to twice its previous energy in order to search for new physics beyond the Higgs boson. It is known that our current understanding of particle physics (as encapsulated within the co-called Standard Model) is not the full story as it does not explain the existence of dark matter, does not explain why our universe has a huge excess of matter over anti-matter, and also does not explain the gravitational force. With support from this award, Professors Nath, Nelson, and Taylor will work to develop new theories that address those issues. Quite remarkably, this work will have direct experimental consequences which can be tested in future experiments at the LHC. Further, their work also has implications for cosmology, and some of their results can be tested in underground experiments looking for signals of dark matter and in satellite experiments searching for dark matter and anti-matter in the universe. Thus the research of these PI's will enhance our understanding of the basic components of the universe. This area of research advances the national interest in that it allows us to push the boundaries of science and test the laws of physics which have thus far not been tested at such large energies. The results arising from the supported research will be disseminated in a variety of ways: through posting on the archives, through publication in standard journals, through conference talks and workshops, and through more general outreach to the public. In addition there is a strong educational component to the award. The projects supported by the award will be used to train Ph.D. thesis students as well as to mentor undergraduate physics majors regarding developments in particle physics. The award will also allow the continuation of the highly successful TheoryNet outreach program, which brings theoretical physicists from New England universities into high-school physics classrooms from Rhode Island to New Hampshire, reaching an estimated 5,000 high-school students in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 at the Large Hadron Collider at the Central European Organization for Nuclear Research in Geneva, Switzerland indicates the presence of new physics beyond the Standard Model. This is so because the measurements of the Higgs boson and the top quark mass indicate that stability of the universe is not guaranteed up to high scales, while supersymmetry, and its more complete version, the supergravity theory, guarantee stability up to the Planck scale. This is another indication that while the Standard Model can only explain physical phenomena up to the Tera electron volt energy scale, supersymmetry, supergravity and strings allow one to extrapolate physics up to the time of the Big Bang.

The effort on NSF PHY-1620575 was geared to discovery of new physics consistent with the Higgs boson mass measurement. Thus in several works one of the PIs, explored techniques for the discovery of the new type of particles known as sparticles, predicted by supersymmetry and supergravity based models. These techniques can be used for the exploration of sparticles at the High Luminosity Hadron Collider which is expected to start its operation in the very near future. Other areas explored concerned ultralight dark matter, using axions, which can explain the structure of galaxies at small scales which are not easily explained by the conventional weakly interacting massive particles. Models of inflation using axions, specically the supersymmetric Dirac-Born-Infeld model was proposed which can produce a large ratio of the tensor to scalar power spectrum, and observable gravity waves, and would be tested in experiments in the future.

As a unifying theory, string theory is the most promising candidate, but phenomena which may indirectly indicate its presence are often difficult to identify. If string theory is operational at experimentally accessible scales, then colliders may provide an opportunity to directly test string theory. Effort on this grant went into precisely such investigations, as well as more formal study of scattering amplitudes. The structure of amplitudes describing the scattering of massless and massive string excitations was investigated at the disk and loop levels. The relations between gauge amplitudes and gravitational amplitudes were investigated and deep connections between gauge theories and general relativity were exhibited.

String phenomenology in a more traditonal, top-down, approach was pursued, utilizing techniques of computational algebraic geometry to search for acceptable string vacua that can encompass the Standard Model. This effort was modernized to include techniques from the world of Big Data, including supervised machine learning using neural networks, reinforcement learning, and network science. These techniques were generally not often used in string theory prior to the effort in this award.
